case_vignette:
A 37‐year‐old woman presents with a severe, deep, sharp pain in her right hand and forearm. A week before she presented her pain symptoms, she fell on her right forearm and developed mild bruising. She has type-1 diabetes mellitus and is on an insulin treatment. The physical examination reveals that her right hand and forearm were warmer, more swollen, and had a more reddish appearance than the left side. She feels an intense pain upon light touching of her right hand and forearm. Her radial and brachial pulses are palpable. The neurological examination is otherwise normal. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 15.2 g/dL
White blood cell count 6,700 cells/cm3
Platelets 300,000 cells/cm3
Alanine aminotransferase 32 units/L
Aspartate aminotransferase 38 units/L
C-reactive protein 0.4 mg/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 7 mm/1st hour
The X-ray of the right hand and forearm do not show a fracture. The nerve conduction studies are also within normal limits.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing severe, deep, sharp pain in my right hand and forearm.
How long have you been experiencing this pain?
The pain started a week ago.
Do you have any other symptoms like numbness or tingling in your right hand or forearm?
No, there's no numbness or tingling, just intense pain when the area is touched lightly.
Have you experienced any injury or trauma to your right hand or forearm recently?
Yes, I fell on my right forearm a week before the pain started and got some mild bruising.
Are you currently taking any medications for any other conditions? If so, what are they?
I am on insulin treatment for my type-1 diabetes mellitus.
Is there a history of diabetes or any other autoimmune diseases in your family?
I'm sorry, but I don't have information about my family's medical history to share.

Based on your symptoms and medical history, it appears that you may be experiencing complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) following the trauma to your right forearm. However, further evaluation by a healthcare professional is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
